title: Knowing Is (Only) Half the Battle
abstract: Editorials5 March 2019Knowing Is (Only) Half the BattleAaron M. Tannenbaum, MD and Scott D. Halpern, MD, PhDAaron M. Tannenbaum, MDPerelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (A.M.T., S.D.H.) and Scott D. Halpern, MD, PhDPerelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania (A.M.T., S.D.H.)Author, Article, and Disclosure Informationhttps://doi.org/10.7326/M18-3691 SectionsAboutFull TextPDF ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack CitationsPermissions ShareFacebookTwitterLinkedInRedditEmail Although a "high-quality medical decision" has no universally accepted definition (1), most would agree that, at a minimum, it reflects a choice that is medically feasible and intended to promote the values of the patient. Yet in the context of critical illness, meeting even this minimum standard is challenging because patients are often incapacitated, their prognoses are uncertain, and the decisions required are emotionally charged and highly consequential. Prevailing wisdom and professional society guidelines (2) suggest that a process-oriented benchmark for which to strive is deliberative shared decision making that promotes patient goals.
